title: How to Plant a Bush

steps.headline: Select a bush that is hardy in your area.
steps.description: Not everything for sale in a local garden shop will be hardy. Occasionally shops will offer plants for sale that are only able to grow in your area under special circumstances.

steps.headline: Consult the plant tag for growing recommendations - especially note the cold hardiness and the plant's preference of growing conditions.
steps.description: Ask yourself "Do I have, or can I make, these conditions in my yard?"

steps.headline: Once you have determined a species of plant has a good chance of survival in your yard, select the most healthy and vigorous specimen available.
steps.description: Look for thickest stems, heaviest leaf cover, no broken or dead twigs, etc.

steps.headline: Get the plant home without damaging it.
steps.description: If in the open bed of a pickup, consider covering the plant with some sort of wind protection for the ride home.

steps.headline: Select a spot for the bush in your yard, keeping the following in mind:
steps.description: Growing conditions of the plant. Make sure the plant is getting the recommended amount of sunlight. Easy access to water. Out of reach of a hose means you'll have to carry water in buckets... not an attractive alternative. Protection from hazards such as digging dogs, heavy winds, Downspout torrents, etc.

steps.headline: Dig a hole that is twice as wide and twice as deep as the pot or root-ball of your bush.
steps.description: Set the earth aside on a piece of cardboard or tarp to protect the grass around the hole. (this may not be a consideration in new construction)

steps.headline: Place mulch or well rotted compost in the bottom of the hole.
steps.description: You want a layer that is one fourth to one third the depth of the hole. This will help retain moisture in dry periods and will help retain soil aeration in wet periods.

steps.headline: Toss in a handful of slow release fertilizer.
Add a shovelful or two of dirt to cover the fertilizer somewhat.
Fill the hole with water and allow it to absorb into the compost and surrounding soil.
steps.description: This will soften the surrounding earth for the new roots to grow into and pre-wet the compost.

steps.headline: Remove your bush's roots from the pot or burlap wrap.
Gently spread out any roots that have become pot bound.
Place the root ball centrally in the hole.
Keep the previous soil line on the plant even with ground level.
Back fill the hole around the roots with the earth you removed from the hole earlier, gently tamping the soil to hold the bush upright.
Use the extra earth to form a small berm of earth around the base of the plant.
steps.description: The berm should be just slightly larger around than the top of the bush is... with a wide basin left at the base of the stalk/stem to hold water.

steps.headline: "Water in" your new bush from the top to remove large air pockets and help the soil to settle in down around the roots.
Water the bush by filling the berm/basin once a week and allowing it to percolate down into the bush's roots.
steps.description: You could set up an inexpensive irrigation system to do a smaller, daily watering as well.

steps.headline: Fertilize as recommended on the plant tag... usually once a year just before foliage emerges is best.
